skin_and_mucosal_changes: Solar lentigines on dorsum of hands

cortical_sensation.two_point_discrimination: Normal at 5mm on finger pads bilaterally

general_patient_description: Burning pain in the feet, especially at night.

Nature of sensory loss: Numbness starting in the toes and slowly creeping upwards.
Feeling of walking on cotton wool.
Nature of weakness: Inability to lift the front of the feet, causing toes to drag.
motor_symptoms: Feeling of weakness in the ankles.

otoscopy: Tympanic membranes pearly grey and intact bilaterally.

external_appearance: No gross abnormalities of the external ear.

gums_and_teeth: Teeth appear to be in a good state of repair.
mallampati_score: Class II - Visibility of uvula and soft palate, but tonsils not visible.

lymphadenopathy: Submandibular and submental nodes are not palpable.
carotid_bruits: Carotid upstrokes are of normal character, no bruits appreciated.

apex_beat_location: Apex beat location is within normal limits.
heaves_and_thrills: Palpation of the precordium is unremarkable.

heart_sounds: No gallop rhythm (S3 or S4) heard.

peripheral_oedema: No pitting oedema noted in the lower limbs.

respiratory_rate_and_effort: Patient is not breathless at rest.
chest_shape_and_symmetry: No surgical scars or deformities noted.

bowel_sounds: Auscultation of the abdomen is unremarkable.

inguinal_region: Femoral pulses are palpable, no masses.

inspection: Trachea is midline. No scars or visible goitre.

sphincter_tone: Good voluntary squeeze on digital rectal exam.
rectal_walls: Rectal mucosa feels smooth and unremarkable.
stool_on_glove: Stool is normal in colour and consistency.

currentSyndrome: Having difficulty concentrating because I'm tired
Feeling tired and irritable during the day
Waking up early and not being able to get back to sleep
The pain getting worse with movement
Feeling very sensitive to light, sounds, and smells

Pain is so severe it limits concentration and social interaction
Inability to perform light household tasks or personal care due to pain

prenatal_history: Normal prenatal course; no known maternal illness or substance exposure.
birth_history: Born at full term via spontaneous vaginal delivery; no complications.
milestones: Achieved all motor and language milestones at appropriate ages.
childhood_illnesses: Normal childhood illnesses only; no significant medical history.
education_history: No known learning difficulties; mainstream education.

Chromosomal Microarray (CMA).result: No clinically significant copy number variants detected

Video-EEG Telemetry (per 24h).report_summary: Normal inpatient video-EEG monitoring. No epileptic events captured.

Visual Evoked Potentials (VEP).P100 Latency: Absolute P100 latencies are within normal limits bilaterally (e.g., <115ms).
Visual Evoked Potentials (VEP).Amplitude & Morphology: P100 amplitudes are symmetrical and of normal morphology.

Brainstem Auditory Evoked Potentials (BA.Wave Latencies: Absolute latencies of waves I, III, and V are present and within normal limits.
Brainstem Auditory Evoked Potentials (BA.Interpeak Latencies: I-III, III-V, and I-V interpeak latencies are normal, indicating normal conduction through the central auditory pathways.

Somatosensory Evoked Potentials (SSEP) -.Peripheral & Central Conduction: Normal latencies for Erb's point, cervical cord (N13), and cortical (N20) potentials following median/ulnar nerve stimulation.
Somatosensory Evoked Potentials (SSEP) -.Conclusion: Normal upper limb somatosensory evoked potentials.

Somatosensory Evoked Potentials (SSEP) -.Peripheral & Central Conduction: Normal latencies for popliteal fossa, lumbar cord, and cortical (P40) potentials following tibial nerve stimulation.
Somatosensory Evoked Potentials (SSEP) -.Conclusion: Normal lower limb somatosensory evoked potentials.

X-Ray.Chest X-Ray (CXR): Clear lung fields, no consolidation. Normal cardiac silhouette. No pleural effusion.

Computed Tomography (CT).CT Head (Non-Contrast): No evidence of acute intracranial haemorrhage, infarct, or space-occupying lesion. Normal ventricular system.
Computed Tomography (CT).CT Head with Contrast: No abnormally enhancing parenchymal or extra-axial lesions.
Computed Tomography (CT).CT Angiogram (Head & Neck): The visualized intracranial and neck vessels are patent without evidence of significant stenosis, occlusion, aneurysm, or dissection.
Computed Tomography (CT).CT Venogram (Head): The major dural venous sinuses and deep cerebral veins are patent.
Computed Tomography (CT).CT Chest, Abdomen, Pelvis (CAP) with Con: No evidence of metastatic disease. No significant lymphadenopathy. Organs appear unremarkable.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Brain: The ventricles, sulci, and cisterns are normal in size and configuration for the patient's age. Normal grey-white matter differentiation is demonstrated. There are no areas of abnormal signal on T2-weighted or FLAIR sequences to suggest oedema, gliosis, or demyelination. No evidence of restricted diffusion on DWI to suggest acute infarction. No evidence of haemorrhage or abnormal mineral deposition on susceptibility-weighted imaging. Following contrast administration, there is no abnormal parenchymal, leptomeningeal, or dural enhancement. The visualized major intracranial vessels are patent. Conclusion: Normal MRI of the brain.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Orbits: The globes, optic nerves, and extraocular muscles are normal in size, course, and signal intensity. The intraconal and extraconal fat appears normal. No abnormal mass or inflammation is identified. Following contrast administration, there is no abnormal enhancement. Conclusion: Normal MRI of the orbits.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Cervical Spine: Normal cervical vertebral body heights and alignment are demonstrated. The intervertebral discs show normal height and T2-signal hydration. The cervical spinal cord is of normal calibre and demonstrates normal signal intensity throughout. There is no significant central canal or neural foraminal stenosis. Following contrast administration, there is no abnormal enhancement of the spinal cord, nerve roots, or surrounding tissues. Conclusion: Normal MRI of the cervical spine.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Thoracic Spine: Normal thoracic vertebral body heights and alignment are demonstrated. The intervertebral discs show normal height and T2-signal hydration. The thoracic spinal cord is of normal calibre and demonstrates normal signal intensity throughout. There is no significant central canal or neural foraminal stenosis. Following contrast administration, there is no abnormal enhancement of the spinal cord or surrounding tissues. Conclusion: Normal MRI of the thoracic spine.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Lumbar Spine: Normal lumbar vertebral body heights and alignment are demonstrated. The conus medullaris terminates at the L1/2 level. The intervertebral discs show normal height and T2-signal hydration. There is no significant central canal or neural foraminal stenosis. The nerve roots of the cauda equina are unremarkable. Following contrast administration, there is no abnormal enhancement. Conclusion: Normal MRI of the lumbar spine.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Brachial Plexus (MR Neurography): The brachial plexus roots, trunks, divisions, and cords are symmetric and show normal signal intensity without evidence of oedema, thickening, or mass lesion. The surrounding musculature and soft tissues are unremarkable. Conclusion: Normal MR neurography of the brachial plexus.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Lumbosacral Plexus (MR Neurography): The lumbosacral plexus roots and major nerves (sciatic, femoral) are symmetric and show normal signal intensity without evidence of oedema, thickening, or mass lesion. The surrounding musculature and soft tissues are unremarkable. Conclusion: Normal MR neurography of the lumbosacral plexus.
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).MRI Muscle Lower limbs: The muscles of the thighs and lower legs are symmetric in bulk and demonstrate homogeneous, normal signal intensity on all sequences. There is no evidence of muscle oedema on STIR or T2 fat-saturated images. There is no evidence of fatty infiltration on T1-weighted images. The fascial planes are unremarkable. Conclusion: Normal MRI of the lower limb musculature.

Nuclear Medicine.DaTSCAN (SPECT): Normal, symmetrical, comma-shaped bilateral striatal uptake, consistent with a non-dopaminergic deficit syndrome.
Nuclear Medicine.FDG-PET Brain: Symmetrical and normal pattern of cerebral glucose metabolism for age, with no focal areas of significant hyper- or hypometabolism.
Nuclear Medicine.Amyloid PET: Negative for significant cortical amyloid plaque deposition.

Ultrasound.Carotid Doppler: No evidence of haemodynamically significant stenosis in the common, internal, or external carotid arteries bilaterally. Normal flow velocities.
Ultrasound.Transcranial Doppler (TCD): Normal flow velocities and pulsatility indices in the major intracranial arteries (MCA, ACA, PCA, Vertebral, Basilar).

Cardiac.Electrocardiogram (ECG): Normal sinus rhythm, heart rate 60-100 bpm, normal axis, no acute ST elevation or depression, normal intervals (PR, QRS, QTc).
Cardiac.24-hour Holter Monitor: Predominantly sinus rhythm. No significant arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia), pauses, or high-grade AV block. Normal heart rate variability.
Cardiac.Echocardiogram (Transthoracic): Normal left ventricular size and systolic function (EF >55%). Normal right ventricular size and function. No significant valvular stenosis or regurgitation. No patent foramen ovale (PFO) on bubble study.
Cardiac.Tilt Table Test: Normal haemodynamic response to orthostatic challenge. No evidence of orthostatic hypotension, postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS), or vasovagal syncope.

Spirometry (Pulmonary Function Tests).Pattern: No evidence of obstructive or restrictive deficit.

Respiratory.Polysomnography (Full Sleep Study): Normal sleep architecture with appropriate proportions of N1, N2, N3, and REM sleep. Apnoea-Hypopnoea Index (AHI) is <5 events/hour. No significant periodic limb movements or other sleep-related disorders.

Autonomic Function Screen.Heart Rate Variability: Normal heart rate response to deep breathing and Valsalva manoeuvre.
Autonomic Function Screen.QSART (Quantitative Sudomotor Axon Refle: Normal, symmetrical sweat output in all tested limbs.
Autonomic Function Screen.Thermoregulatory Sweat Test: Normal, symmetrical sweat response to warming.
Autonomic Function Screen.Conclusion: No evidence of a significant autonomic neuropathy.

Neuro-ophthalmology.Formal Visual Field Testing (Perimetry): Full visual fields bilaterally. No evidence of scotoma, quadrantanopia, or hemianopia.
Neuro-ophthalmology.Fundus Photography / Optical Coherence T: Normal optic discs with sharp margins and no pallor or swelling. Normal retinal nerve fibre layer (RNFL) thickness. Maculae are healthy.
